persona.name: Sunita Devi

occupation.title: Smallholder farmer and seasonal informal laborer
occupation.description: Primary livelihood is small-scale agriculture on a 0.6 hectare mixed plot (rice/maize/pulse rotation) with a small kitchen garden and two goats. Works as the main manager of household farming tasks: selecting seeds, sowing, weeding, harvesting, and post-harvest cleaning. Sells surplus vegetables and pulses at the weekly haat and to a local shopkeeper. In the lean season she takes on informal day labor—planting and harvesting as a piece-rate worker on larger farms and occasional construction-site work in the nearby small town. She also earns by rearing goats and selling one or two young goats a year. Keeps informal accounts in a small notebook. She is an active member of a women's self-help group (SHG) that pools savings and provides small loans; she sometimes borrows from the SHG for seeds/fertilizer. Skillful at bargaining, seed-saving, composting, and basic animal care. Works without formal contracts, has no social security coverage, and income is seasonal and variable. She regularly sends small remittances (cash) to her younger sister who lives and works in a larger domestic city (Varanasi), helping with that sister's children's schooling and occasional medical costs.

persona.residence: Khetapur village, Gopalganj district, Bihar, India (rural area)
persona.education: Completed secondary school (Class 10) at the government higher secondary school in the nearest block town. Schooling was intermittent: missed a year during adolescence to help with harvests. Basic literacy and numeracy, can fill simple forms, read short messages on a phone; attended a few adult literacy sessions run by a local NGO.
long_term_goals: To secure enough stable income so her two children can complete higher secondary education and one can get vocational training.
To buy a small piece of irrigated land (or add to the existing tiny plot) so the family can grow vegetables year-round and reduce dependence on monsoon.
To build a modest concrete-room addition so elderly mother-in-law has private sleeping space and to have a small storage room for farm inputs.
To see her daughter become financially independent and avoid early marriage pressures.
To be able to repay outstanding informal loans and have at least one season without having to borrow for seeds.
To maintain dignity and respect in the village and be known as someone who helps neighbours in crises.
To pass on practical farming knowledge, seed-saving and herbal remedies to the next generation.
To travel once with family to a nearby city (Patna) for a festival or fair and stay in a proper hotel.
To ensure children are vaccinated and have access to basic healthcare without struggling for cash.
To join or lead a local women's collective that can negotiate better prices at the market.
persona.style: Speaks in a local Bihari-Hindi dialect (Maithili/Hindi intonations depending on interlocutor). Uses polite honorifics for elders (aap, bua, chacha) and more informal, quick speech with peers. Her voice is warm, slightly nasal, and measured; when negotiating in the market she becomes brisk, louder and uses short, direct sentences. Typical mannerisms: touches her forehead with the back of her hand when thinking, fingers seeds or her sari pallu when nervous, smiles readily but reserves deep laughter for close friends, uses proverbs and folk sayings in conversation, often punctuates a point with a small laugh. Dressing style: simple cotton saris (mostly indigo, maroon, or earth tones), cotton blouse, occasional patterned shawl in winter, and plastic sandals. Keeps hair in a loose bun or braid. She greets visitors with chai if available and insists they sit on the charpoy (woven bed). In public she is modest and polite; in private she swears softly when things go wrong. Comfortable with basic mobile phone tasks: voice calls, WhatsApp voice messages, and forwarding short videos; prefers voice notes over typing. Prefers face-to-face conversations for important matters and relies on SHG meetings to resolve community issues. When upset, she writes a quick note or tells an older neighbor rather than broadcasting grievances widely.

traits: Practical: focuses on concrete steps to solve immediate problems (seed, water, cash).
Resilient: has endured crop failures, floods, and family illnesses and continues to adapt.
Warm and nurturing: prioritizes children and elders, often places others' needs before her own.
Cautious with money: meticulously tracks small savings and dislikes wasteful spending.
Sociable and cooperative within the village network; values reciprocity.
Suspicious of outsiders making big promises, especially government schemes that seem 'too good to be true.'
Persistent: returns to tasks until finished; gets up early and works late during peak season.
Proud: takes pride in good harvests, a tidy home, and her children's small achievements.
Occasionally anxious about the future and shocks (drought, illness), which can make her thrifty bordering on stingy with non-essentials.
Traditional but pragmatic: follows customary rituals and festivals, yet will try a new seed variety if neighbours recommend it.
Emotionally stoic in public but confides deeply with a couple of trusted women friends.
Negotiator: skilled at bargaining at markets and with labor contractors.

big_five.openness: 55/100. Curious about practical innovations (new water pump, hybrid seed) but cautious about cultural change.
big_five.conscientiousness: 75/100. Very organized about household finances, planting cycles, and children's school attendance.
big_five.extraversion: 50/100. Sociable and engaged in local networks, comfortable in groups and market settings but values quiet home time.
big_five.agreeableness: 78/100. Cooperative and helpful; willing to compromise for communal harmony.
big_five.neuroticism: 46/100. Moderate worry about finances and health, but generally calm under acute stress and recovers quickly.

interests: Growing seasonal vegetables: particularly okra, spinach, eggplant and gourds.
Saving and bookkeeping: keeping a small blue notebook with day-to-day income and expenses.
Cooking traditional meals: making dal, roti, rice, seasonal vegetable curries and pickles.
Attending the weekly haat: enjoys social exchange, seeing news, and selling produce.
Women's self-help group meetings: likes the rhythm of savings, loan decisions and shared gossip.
Listening to the radio in the morning for weather, government announcements and folk songs.
Local festivals (Chhath Puja, Holi, Diwali): participates fully and enjoys food preparation and ritual duties.
Seed-saving and exchanging seeds with neighbors before planting season.
Hand-embroidery and simple mending: hemming saris and shirts in spare time.
Making herbal remedies: using turmeric, neem, giloy for minor ailments, and mustard oil massages.
Going to the block market occasionally to buy household items and chat with shopkeepers.
Watching a popular regional soap opera on a neighbor's TV once a week.
Keeping goats and watching them graze; finds comfort in their gentle presence.
Teaching her daughter basic counting and reading after school.
Using WhatsApp voice notes to check in with her sister in the city and exchange small news.
Listening to bhajans and local devotional music during early morning chores.
Buying one new piece of cloth or ornament for festivals each year.
Learning about drip irrigation methods from an agricultural extension worker; intrigued by the idea of saving water.
Simple woodcraft and mending tools: fixing a broken plough handle or sewing a sack.
Watching children's games and occasionally joining in during village events.
Making achar (mango or mixed vegetable pickles) with a family recipe.
Collecting and drying seeds from the best-performing plants each season.
Observing cloud patterns and predicting rain from local signs (smell of earth, insect activity).
Following local politics informally through conversations at the tea stall.
Saving small amounts in an SHG piggy bank rather than in cash at home.
Practicing basic hygiene habits taught by health workers (handwashing around food prep).
Comparing fertilizer and pesticide prices carefully and preferring trusted brands.
Enjoying a strong, sweet chai with jaggery in the early morning.
Visiting the primary school occasionally for parent meetings and to check her children's attendance.
Collecting and preserving old family recipes and stories to tell grandchildren later.
likes: The smell of wet earth after the first monsoon rain.
Fresh homemade curd with warm rotis.
A good bargaining win in the haat (feels like a small victory).
Neat rows of seedlings in the nursery bed.
Gifts of seasonal fruit from a neighbor's well-tended tree.
The comfort of a warm mustard oil massage after a long day of bending in fields.
Simple, durable kitchenware: an iron tava, brass lota, clay pots.
Bright saris in maroon or indigo for festivals.
Children coming home with small school prizes or good marks.
Having cash saved for an emergency in the SHG account.
Evening gatherings with women where they stitch, talk and share news.
Receiving a small remittance message or call from a family member in another town.
A goat that grows quickly and yields a good price at market time.
A functioning handpump or nearby tube well that supplies water reliably.
Neighbors who return favors and help during harvest.
Simple, filling snacks: roasted chana, puffed rice with jaggery.
Listening to elders tell stories about when the village was younger and simpler.
When the mid-day sun is not too harsh and work progresses smoothly.
Clear, specific weather forecasts on the radio before sowing.
Locally-made jaggery and mustard oil of familiar taste.
A good conversation with the SHG leader that yields useful advice.
Finding a good quality seed packet at a reasonable price.
A tidy courtyard and a swept kitchen area.
Watching her daughter braid her hair neatly and proudly.
When a borrowed loan is repaid on time and relationships stay intact.
Receiving simple medical advice from an ASHA worker that helps her child recover.
When traders treat her fairly at the haat and buy her vegetables without delay.
A full, nourishing midday meal on a busy harvest day.
The sight of green fields stretching after a few good rains.
Neighbors coming together to repair a shared footpath or pump.
dislikes: Bank officials who ask for many documents and make simple tasks complicated.
Predatory moneylenders who charge crippling interest and shame borrowers.
Crop pests and locust-like infestations that ruin months of work in days.
Late, unreliable rains that delay sowing or damage germination.
High, unexplained electricity or water bills and sudden cessations of supply.
Government paperwork that requires travel to the block and costs a day’s wages.
Youth leaving the village permanently because it breaks family bonds (while also understanding why).
When traders undervalue her produce and try to intimidate her in the market.
Children being scolded harshly at school by inconsistent teachers.
Plastic-wrapped, low-quality goods sold as 'branded' at high price.
Caste-based exclusion when some families are left out of communal labor.
Illnesses that keep a family member bedridden during planting/harvest.
The smell of diesel from noisy pumps that frighten goats and spoil water clarity.
Rumours that unsettle women in the SHG and create mistrust.
Being interrupted during a prayer or ritual.
Heavy fines or penalties levied without explanation by local authorities.
The cost of a sudden operation in the city that drains small savings.
When children skip school to work in fields or as child labor elsewhere.
Soap and cleaning items that cause rashes; she prefers familiar mild soaps.
Sewage or open drains near the house causing flies and odors.
Loud, aggressive salesmen who pressure villagers into technologies they don’t understand.
Being dismissed by a male landowner when asking for fair wages or land access.
Food wastage at festivals when many households are still struggling.
When gifted items (clothes, utensils) are of poor quality or too small.
False promises from NGO workers who visit once and never return.
Heavy rains during the paddy threshing period that dirty grains and lower price.
Long waits at the health sub-center with no medicines available.
Being excluded from market deals because of speaking up as a woman.
Children becoming overly attached to mobile games and neglecting studies.
Contracts or forms that are printed only in English and not explained.

beliefs: Family comes first: household decisions should benefit children and elders before individual wants.
Hard work and early rising are virtues that yield small but steady rewards.
Education is important for children to avoid only manual, insecure work, but practical skills matter too.
Women should be respected and consulted in household matters, yet societal norms still require prudence in how they speak publicly.
Saving small amounts regularly prevents crises more than occasional large sums.
Land, even a small patch, is security; owning or improving land is worth sacrifice.
Traditional remedies often help for common ailments and should be used alongside doctors when necessary.
God and ritual (puja) protect the household; rituals during festivals bind the community.
Community reciprocity (mutual labour, lending tools) is essential for survival in lean times.
Government schemes can help but require local follow-through and often contain hidden conditions.
Loans that trap families in debt are to be avoided; better to borrow from a trusted neighbor or SHG.
Children—especially girls—should be educated, but timing of marriage is influenced by family pressure and finances.
Men are expected to do certain outdoor tasks, but women’s work is equally valuable even if unpaid and unrecognized.
Agricultural knowledge passed down from elders is valuable, but improved seed/hybrid varieties can be tried cautiously.
Water is precious: wells and pumps must be conserved and repaired together as a community responsibility.
Corruption is widespread: officials often expect bribes, and it's better to rely on community leaders to get things done.
Micro-savings and SHGs empower women and provide social space to discuss problems confidentially.
A good roof and secure doors are a symbol of dignity and must be prioritized.
Migrant work is painful but necessary: sending remittances keeps extended family afloat and is an act of obligation and love.
Children should be vaccinated; she follows the village health worker's advice for childhood immunizations.
Caste distinctions exist but everyday cooperation can bridge many divides in practical matters.
Religion provides comfort in times of loss and motivates charitable acts during festivals.
Climate variability has become worse; rains are less predictable than when she was a child and require adaptive practices.
Selecting seeds from the best plants each year leads to more resilience than always buying new seeds.
Local markets and fair prix-setting protect small producers when they coordinate their sales days.
Investing in a handpump or a simple solar pump is a sensible long-term investment for the household.
Young people should learn to read the world (news, phone messages) and balance that with traditional values.
Plastic and cheap packaged food are convenient but less wholesome than home-cooked meals.
Women's voices are stronger when they speak together; solitary complaints often go unheard.
If you help neighbors during hardship, they will help you later; relationships are a social safety-net.
Health is maintained by a mix of diet, rest, and herbal treatments; preventive actions are better than waiting until illness.
Marriage must be carefully planned; a daughter's match should not lead to crippling debt.
Teachers who show kindness are more effective than those who only scold; children's curiosity must be nurtured.
Loans from local traders are risky because they often include hidden terms; transparency is vital.
Small acts of saving and planning can reduce stress during monsoon and harvest seasons.
skills: Practical farming: ploughing with a hired tractor, transplanting paddy, weeding by hand, harvesting by sickle, threshing.
Seed selection and storage: identifying best plants, drying and storing seeds for next season in clay pots or jute sacks.
Compost making and small-scale organic soil improvements using farm waste and cow/goat dung.
Basic veterinary care: treating minor goat illnesses, wound cleaning, dosing with simple medicines.
Market negotiation: pricing produce, bargaining, and choosing buyers; knows which days traders pay more.
Cooking: making balanced seasonal meals, pickling, preparing meals for festivals and guests.
Household budgeting: tracking small daily expenses in her blue notebook, managing cashflows between farm and household.
Basic tailoring and mending: sewing buttons, hemming saris, making simple clothes for children.
Using a basic smartphone: voice calls, WhatsApp voice messages, forwarding small videos, reading simple messages.
First aid and folk remedies: using turmeric poultices, neem leaves, hot compresses and simple herbal teas for colds and fevers.
Group facilitation: speaking up at SHG meetings, helping decide loan disbursements, encouraging repayment culture.
Identifying common pests and basic pest-management (hand-picking, using neem-based solutions).
Time management under seasonality: coordinating labour, arranging for hired help during peak times.
Basic record keeping: recording SHG contributions, loans, and crop yields in a notebook.
Childcare and early education: encouraging counting, simple reading and helping with school lessons in the evenings.

general: Greets elders with a slight bow of the head and touches feet on special occasions.
Sips morning chai standing in the courtyard, then begins the first round of checking the animals and fields.
Uses hand gestures frequently when telling stories, particularly with her hands describing crop rows or market queues.
Prefers to send a voice note than type long messages; voice messages are often long, descriptive and include gossip.
Keeps a small blue notebook where she records daily cash inflows and outflows; consults it before spending.
Shares food and small portions with neighbours during festivals and emergencies; reciprocity is habitual.
Laughs heartily with close women friends and can be quiet and reserved in the presence of unknown men or officials.
When anxious about money, reduces non-essential purchases and freezes spending for a week to rebuild savings.
When there is an argument about land or wages, she seeks older male relatives to mediate but participates actively in discussions.
Attends the weekly haat both to sell produce and gather news, often staying to drink tea and discuss politics.

morning: Wakes around 5:00 AM; performs a short prayer/puja and lights a diya on special days.
Prepares a simple breakfast: leftover rice or roti with pickles or lentils and a strong cup of chai.
Feeds goats and checks the courtyard, waters the kitchen garden, and inspects seedlings.
If market day, packs vegetables, ties them carefully in clean sacks and sets off to the haat by 7:00 AM.
If a heavy field day, coordinates hired labour, directs transplanting, or spends time weeding.
workday: Most work is outside until midday: planting, weeding, fetching water and tending animals.
Returns home for a mid-day meal and rests briefly to conserve energy during peak sun hours.
Afternoons devoted to household tasks: mending, cooking, talking with neighbours about seed exchange, SHG matters.
If necessary, takes piece-rate work on other farms in the late afternoon or goes to the small town for wage labor.
Checks mobile phone late afternoon for a call from her sister in the city and listens to updates about remittances and family news.
evening: Prepares evening meal by 6:30 PM, usually vegetable curry, dal and roti or rice depending on harvest.
Family eats together when possible; she supervises children's homework if electricity allows.
Attends short SHG meetings twice a month; otherwise sits on the charpoy to chat with neighbours or listen to the radio.
Lights a small lamp in the prayer corner on festival days and sings simple devotional songs with children.
Goes to sleep around 9:30–10:00 PM after checking that animals are secure and doors are latched.
weekend: Saturdays may be used for visiting the block or market to procure fertilizer, seeds, or check on construction contractors.
Sundays are for family: preparing special food, visiting relatives, participating in village events or ceremonies, minor repairs around the home.
Participates in community labour exchanges when the village schedules shared tasks such as well-cleaning or communal threshing.

health.physical: Generally robust for a manual worker but carries chronic lower-back pain from years of bending in fields and carrying sacks; has mild iron-deficiency anemia (occasional fatigue, diagnosed once during a health camp); recovered from two bouts of severe diarrhea in childhood of her children, keeps ORS packets at home; had one uncomplicated pregnancy and vaginal deliveries at the local primary health centre (nearest facility 12 km away); occasional seasonal respiratory issues during winter and dust exposure; observes basic preventive hygiene and uses herbal treatments first for minor ailments; eyesight slightly reduced (reads small print with difficulty) but hasn't had access to affordable spectacles.
health.mental: Moderate stress related to financial insecurity and unpredictability of rains; resilient outlook, sleeps reasonably well most nights; sometimes feels low for a few days after a bad harvest but rebounds after taking action (selling a goat, taking a day labor job); values social support and confides mainly in her sister and two close friends; not diagnosed with clinical depression or anxiety but experiences episodic worry.
medical_history: Had a minor fracture of the wrist in youth from a fall; healed without complications.
Anemia detected during a maternal health check five years ago; took iron tablets intermittently.
Children have received basic immunizations through village health worker outreach.
Occasional visits to the block health center for fever and respiratory infections.
access_and_behaviors: Relies on local ASHA/ANM for vaccinations and advice; prefers local remedies first then the public clinic if worsening.
Uses mustard oil massages and turmeric poultices for aches.
Keeps a small medicine box with common analgesics, ORS and some antibiotics left over from prior prescriptions (advice-based reuse).
Finds travel to outside hospitals expensive and disruptive to farm work, so postpones non-urgent care.
Accepts family planning counseling but decisions are negotiated with her husband and elder family members.

relationships.name: Ramesh Prasad
relationships.description: A quiet, stoic man who works irregularly as a tractor driver and seasonal laborer. Contributes to farming decisions, prefers taking loans from known neighbours. Shares responsibilities in the field and cares about maintaining family honour.

relationships.name: Neha Kumari
relationships.description: Attends the nearest secondary school, good at arithmetic, helps mother with household work, aspires to be a nurse's aide. Mother is protective of her schooling and wary of early marriage proposals.

relationships.name: Manish Kumar
relationships.description: Recently completed Class 10; works seasonally in the nearby town on construction and as a delivery assistant. Sends small weekly remittances to the family. Sunita worries about him migrating permanently but appreciates his earnings.

relationships.name: Radha Devi
relationships.description: Lives in the same household; traditional, authoritative on household rituals; has mobility limits but is respected. Sunita helps with her care and negotiates food choices to keep peace.

relationships.name: Geeta Sinha
relationships.description: Meets weekly; confides in Geeta about money and family; they exchange seeds and recipes. Geeta sometimes lends her a sari for festivals.

relationships.name: Sukhi Lal
relationships.description: Sells household staples and gives small credit; Sunita trusts him for timely loans but is careful to keep accounts clear.

relationships.name: Anita
relationships.description: Works in a textile unit and receives remittances from Sunita occasionally; reciprocates with city-sourced goods and occasional cash help when Sunita had health expenses.

relationships.name: SHG group (8 women)
relationships.description: Meet twice a month for savings and lending; they share information about agriculture, government schemes, and childcare. Sunita is an active participant and sometimes volunteers to collect signatures for local initiatives.

relationships.name: Village head (mukhiya)
relationships.description: Sunita interacts with him occasionally for water-pump repairs, land disputes and local festivals. She respects his position but privately criticizes slow action.

relationships.name: School teacher (primary)
relationships.description: Friendly but overburdened; Sunita meets with her on parent-teacher days to check children's progress.

other_facts: Born in the same village; family has lived there for three generations on small plots of land.
Was married at age 18 in an arranged marriage; husband is from a neighbouring village.
Her household consists of three generations: herself, husband, two children and her mother-in-law; an unmarried cousin sometimes stays during busy seasons.
Keeps a small clay pot with a brass coin as a simple family shrine corner for daily prayers.
Has one piece of ID (Aadhaar) and a small public bank account opened through a camp; uses bank mainly to receive government payments.
Used an NGO loan five years ago to buy two goats; repaid on schedule despite a bad monsoon that year.
Was part of a participatory training on soil health two seasons ago and introduced composting afterward.
Has a standing monthly ritual of cleaning the courtyard thoroughly before festival days; neighbors comment positively on her neatness.
Remits roughly 1,000–1,500 rupees per month to her sister in the city when possible; sometimes sends cloth, pulses or home-cooked sweets instead of cash.
Participated in a village labour gang the year government offered paid manual work (MGNREGA), but payments were delayed and she had to borrow to meet immediate needs.
Keeps an old bicycle in repair to visit the small town (10 km) when needed; sometimes borrows a neighbor’s rickshaw for bulky purchases.
Has a memory of a particularly bountiful year when her son was born and the family celebrated with a large meal that many still talk about.
Once had to sell a golden thread bangle (family keepsake) to pay for an emergency medical trip to the city; she still regrets having sold it.
Maintains a small patch of medicinal herbs behind the house: tulsi, neem, aloe and kalmegh (and uses them regularly).
Her favourite recipe is 'sattu paratha' (roasted gram flour stuffed flatbread) made on festival mornings.
Her younger brother migrated once to Mumbai for three years as a cycle-rickshaw mechanic and returned with savings that helped repair the house roof; he is a cautionary tale of city life.
She remembers a flood five years ago that washed a neighbor's hut away; the community pooled resources to help rebuild that family.
Learned basic numeracy by helping her mother in a small family shop as a teenager; this is where she developed confidence in counting change.
Has a small wooden trunk with certificates and wedding photos; shows them with pride to visitors.
Does simple seasonal food preservation: sun-dried vegetables and pickles in earthen pots, stored for scarcity months.
Has a neighbor who runs a small tailoring service and mends children's school uniforms when needed; Sunita often refers others to her.
Keeps a list of emergency phone numbers by the charpoy (ASHA worker, local shopkeeper, cousin in the block town).
Remembers schoolteachers who encouraged her and promised to help her kids get scholarships; she plans to meet them during admission season.
Has informal arrangements with two farms to share labor during planting; they rotate labour in kind without cash exchange.
Knows the exact pattern of the lunar calendar for timing certain seed sowings and festivals; family keeps to that schedule.
Her son once brought home a small radio from his first wage job as a gift to the household; it is cherished and used for news and music.
Occasionally journeys to the block-level government office with a neighbor to access ration cards or entitlements; it takes a whole day but they manage together.
Has a habit of saving small notes in a hidden tin under the hearth for sudden travel or funeral costs; it's a private reserve.
Was once approached by a private seed salesman with persuasive promises; after a poor germination she stopped buying from that brand and prefers community recommendations.
Keeps photographs of her children at school pinned on a kitchen wall next to a calendar with festival dates and government clinic days.
Remembers the name and story of an elder woman who taught her an old chant for calming children during fevers; she uses it sometimes to soothe her daughter.
Took a short two-day training in basic bookkeeping run by an NGO and improved her SHG record-keeping afterward.
Has a recurring small dream of building a proper utility room to keep grain and tools dry; sketches a rudimentary plan when she can spare time.
Has lent small amounts to neighbours during festival seasons and remembers well who repaid on time; maintains a mental ledger of social trust.
Knows how to sing two popular folk tunes used in harvest celebrations and leads them when neighbors gather to thresh.
Once hosted a neighbor's child for a month while their parents migrated for work; the experience made her realize the additional emotional burden on left-behind caregivers.
Keeps a lightweight plastic umbrella and a wide-brimmed straw hat for sudden rain during market days.
Has a pattern of making a special sweet (laddoo) from jaggery and roasted gram for auspicious occasions and distributes it among neighbors.
Participated in a local dispute once where land boundary lines were unclear; the village committee mediated and she remembers how drawn-out and stressful it was.
Keeps an old list of traditional remedies for 15 common ailments in her head and occasionally shares this knowledge at women's meetings.
